question:
Around which year did Robert Brown publish a paper highlighting the presence of a nucleus in plant cells?

SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• Robert Brown was a Scottish botanist who made a significant contribution to cell biology.
  • In 1831, he observed and described the nucleus in plant cells while studying orchid epidermal cells.
  • He presented this finding in a paper in the early 1830s, formally introducing the term "nucleus" in 1833.
  • His discovery laid the foundation for the later understanding of cell structure and function.

Additional Information:

  • Robert Hooke first coined the term "cell" in 1665.
  • The nucleus is the central organelle in eukaryotic cells that contains genetic material.
  • The presence of a nucleus is a key feature distinguishing eukaryotic cells from prokaryotic cells.

question:
Who explained the structure of protein?

SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The structure of proteins, particularly the secondary structure (like alpha-helix and beta-sheet), was explained by Linus Pauling and Robert Corey in the 1950s.
  • They proposed that the polypeptide chain folds into specific shapes stabilized by hydrogen bonds.
  • Their work was fundamental in understanding protein folding and molecular biology.

Additional Information:

  • Emil Fischer worked on the structure of amino acids and peptide bonds, not the 3D structure of proteins.
  • Johnson and Cristae and RF Rose are not associated with protein structure discovery.
  • Linus Pauling later received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry (1954) for his work on the nature of the chemical bond, including insights into biological molecules.

question:
In 1873, who published the first photograph of nerve tissue stained with the black reaction technique, describing a whole nerve cell?

SSC MTS 01/09/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• In 1873, Camillo Golgi, an Italian physician and scientist, developed a staining technique called the "black reaction" (reazione nera).
  • This method used silver nitrate to stain nerve tissue, allowing the entire structure of a neuron to be visualized clearly under a microscope.
  • Golgi’s technique was groundbreaking as it enabled the observation of the whole nerve cell, including dendrites and axons, for the first time.
  • This laid the foundation for neuroscience and helped Santiago Ramón y Cajal later develop the Neuron Doctrine.

Additional Information:

  • Gunter Blobel discovered signal peptides in protein targeting (Nobel Prize in 1999).
  • William Harvey discovered the circulation of blood.
  • Paul Ehrlich worked on immunology and chemotherapy, but not neuron staining.

question:
Which bacteria was discovered by Barry Marshall and Robin Warren that colonises the human stomach and causes chronic superficial gastritis ulcers?

SSC MTS 13/09/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• Helicobacter pylori is a spiral-shaped bacterium that colonizes the lining of the human stomach.
  • It was discovered in the early 1980s by Barry Marshall and Robin Warren, who demonstrated its role in chronic superficial gastritis and peptic ulcers.
  • Their discovery revolutionized the treatment of ulcers, shifting from antacids to antibiotic therapy.
  • They were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2005 for this groundbreaking work.

Additional Information:

  • Campylobacter jejuni causes food poisoning and gastroenteritis.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the causative agent of gonorrhea, a sexually transmitted infection.
  • Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebiasis, affecting the intestines and liver.

question:
Who coined the word ‘cell’ in the 1600s, from the Latin word ‘cellula’, meaning ‘small room’?

SSC MTS 13/09/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The term "cell" was coined by Robert Hooke in 1665 when he observed thin slices of cork under a primitive microscope.
  • He noticed small box-like structures that reminded him of monastic cells or small rooms, hence he used the Latin word "cellula" meaning "small room."
  • Although Hooke only saw cell walls (the cork cells were dead), his naming laid the foundation for cell theory.

Additional Information:

  • Louis Pasteur was a pioneer in microbiology, known for pasteurization and germ theory, not for cell discovery.
  • Theodor Schwann was part of the team that developed cell theory, stating all animals are made of cells.
  • Lynn Margulis proposed the endosymbiotic theory explaining the origin of eukaryotic cells.

question:
Which cytologist demonstrated the role of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) in protein processing and sorting in a variety of cells in the 1960s ?

SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• In the 1960s, George E. Palade, a Romanian-American cell biologist, played a pioneering role in uncovering the function of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).
  • He used electron microscopy and cell fractionation to show that the rough ER (with ribosomes) is involved in protein synthesis, processing, and sorting in eukaryotic cells.
  • Palade discovered how proteins move from the rough ER → Golgi apparatus → final destinations like lysosomes, plasma membrane, or secretion outside the cell.
  • His work laid the foundation of modern cell biology, especially in understanding the secretory pathway.

Additional Information:

  • Ralph M. Steinman discovered dendritic cells in immunology.
  • Nettie Stevens is known for discovering the role of sex chromosomes (X and Y) in determining gender.
  • Cyril Darlington contributed to chromosome behavior and genetics, but not to ER-related functions.

question:
Which of the following personalities is a well-known Indian plant physiologist and physicist ?

SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Jagadish Chandra Bose (JC Bose) was a renowned Indian physicist and plant physiologist.
  • He made pioneering contributions in demonstrating that plants respond to stimuli, much like animals.
  • He invented the crescograph, an instrument that measures the growth of plants and records their responses to various stimuli.
  • JC Bose is also regarded as a founder of experimental science in India, contributing to radio science and biophysics.

Additional Information:

  • C.V. Raman was a physicist known for discovering the Raman Effect in light scattering (Nobel Prize, 1930).
  • C.N.R. Rao is a prominent chemist known for his work in solid-state and structural chemistry.
  • J.R.D. Tata was a leading Indian industrialist and aviation pioneer, not a scientist.

question:
In which year did Rudolf Ludwig Karl Virchow formulate his famous aphorism ‘Omnis cellula-e cellula’ which became a part of the foundation of cell theory?

SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• The phrase "Omnis cellula e cellula", meaning "Every cell arises from a pre-existing cell", was coined by Rudolf Ludwig Karl Virchow in the year 1855.
  • This idea opposed the earlier belief of spontaneous generation and became a crucial addition to the modern cell theory.
  • Virchow emphasized that cell division is the method by which new cells form, which is fundamental to understanding growth, healing, and disease processes.

Additional Information:

  • This concept is now considered the third tenet of cell theory:
    1. All living things are made of cells.
    2. The cell is the basic unit of life.
    3. All cells arise from pre-existing cells.
  • Theodor Schwann and Matthias Schleiden earlier proposed the basic cell theory in the 1830s–40s but did not include this principle.

question:
Single-celled life forms were discovered by Anton Van Leeuwenhoek in __________ .

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Anton van Leeuwenhoek, a Dutch scientist, is credited with the discovery of single-celled life forms in the year 1674.
  • Using a simple single-lens microscope that he designed himself, he was the first to observe and describe microorganisms, which he called “animalcules.”
  • His observations included bacteria, protozoa, and other microscopic organisms found in pond water, saliva, and other substances.
  • This was a foundational moment in the development of microbiology.

Additional Information:

  • 1774, 1837, and 1884 are not relevant to the initial discovery of microorganisms.
  • Leeuwenhoek is often referred to as the “Father of Microbiology.”
  • His findings were communicated to the Royal Society of London, which later published them.

question:
In which year did E Gorter and F Grendel make a breakthrough by examining the surface area of lipids and concluded that the lipid surface surrounding cells must be of two layers?

SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• In 1925, Evert Gorter and Francois Grendel conducted a classic experiment using red blood cells to study the lipid composition of cell membranes.
  • They extracted lipids from the red blood cell membranes and spread them into a monolayer on a water surface.
  • They discovered that the surface area of the lipid film was approximately twice the surface area of the actual cells.
  • This led them to conclude that the cell membrane is composed of a lipid bilayer—two layers of lipid molecules.
  • Their work provided the first experimental evidence supporting the lipid bilayer model of biological membranes.

Additional Information:

  • The Fluid Mosaic Model of the membrane was proposed later in 1972 by Singer and Nicolson.
  • The bilayer structure is crucial for membrane fluidity, permeability, and functionality.

question:
In Which year did an American cytogeneticist named Joe Hin Tjio publish a research finding that defined 2n=46 as the exact number of human chromosomes?

SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• In the year 1956, Joe Hin Tjio, an American cytogeneticist of Indonesian origin, made a landmark discovery in human genetics.
  • Working with Albert Levan, he used improved techniques for chromosome preparation and staining, allowing accurate counting.
  • They conclusively determined that the diploid number (2n) of human chromosomes is 46, not 48 as previously thought.
  • This discovery corrected a long-standing error and became a foundational element in human cytogenetics.

Additional Information:

  • The previous incorrect count of 48 chromosomes persisted for decades due to limitations in microscopy and staining methods.
  • The finding was published in 1956 and led to advances in the diagnosis of chromosomal disorders such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21).

question:
In which year did Walther Flemming coined the term ‘chromatin’ for the stained substance found in the cell nucleus?

SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• In 1879, Walther Flemming, a German biologist and cytologist, coined the term "chromatin" to describe the deeply stained material he observed in the cell nucleus during cell division.
  • Using advanced staining techniques and microscopes, he studied the process of mitosis and noticed that certain nuclear substances took up stains strongly.
  • He named this substance "chromatin" from the Greek word "chroma" meaning color, because of its strong affinity to dyes.
  • Flemming’s observations laid the groundwork for understanding chromosome behavior during cell division.

Additional Information:

  • Flemming is also credited with being one of the first scientists to describe mitosis in detail.
  • The term chromosome was introduced later by Waldeyer-Hartz in 1888.

question:
Which ecologist is famous for studying plant life in the Indiana Dunes in 1896 ?

SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• In 1896, Henry Chandler Cowles, an American ecologist, conducted pioneering research on plant succession in the Indiana Dunes along the southern shore of Lake Michigan.
  • His studies focused on how plant communities change over time in response to environmental conditions—a concept known as ecological succession.
  • Cowles’ work in the Indiana Dunes is considered a foundational contribution to the field of ecology, particularly plant ecology and succession theory.

Additional Information:

  • Robert MacArthur is known for his work on island biogeography and niche theory.
  • G. Evelyn Hutchinson is regarded as the "father of modern ecology," known for work on limnology and ecological niches.
  • Aldo Leopold is famous for his contributions to wildlife ecology and land ethics, especially through his book A Sand County Almanac.

question:
Which among the following are commonly known as blood thinners?

SSC MTS 18/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Anticoagulants are commonly referred to as blood thinners.
  • They do not actually thin the blood, but rather prevent blood clots from forming or growing larger.
  • These drugs are used to treat or prevent conditions such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), stroke, and heart attacks.
  • Common anticoagulants include warfarin, heparin, and dabigatran.

Additional Information:

  • Antibiotics fight bacterial infections.
  • Anticaking agents prevent lumps in powdered or granulated materials.
  • Antibodies are immune system proteins that identify and neutralize pathogens like bacteria and viruses.

question:
Which of the following was the first B vitamin discovered in 1897 ?

SSC CGL Tier-II 02/03/2023
solution:
• The first B vitamin to be discovered was Thiamine (Vitamin B1) in the year 1897.
  • It was isolated by Christiaan Eijkman, a Dutch physician, while studying beriberi, a disease caused by thiamine deficiency.
  • He found that polished (white) rice lacked a factor present in unpolished (brown) rice, which helped prevent beriberi.
  • Thiamine is essential for carbohydrate metabolism and proper functioning of the nervous system.

Additional Information:

  • Folate (Vitamin B9) was discovered later in the 20th century.
  • Biotin (Vitamin B7) was isolated in the 1930s.
  • Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) was identified in the 1920s–1930s.

question:
Who explained the structure and reproductive system of algae in 1935 ?

SSC CGL Tier-II 06/03/2023
solution:
• In 1935, F.E. Fritsch (Frederick Ernest Fritsch), a British botanist, provided a comprehensive explanation of the structure and reproductive system of algae.
  • His major work, “The Structure and Reproduction of the Algae,” is considered a landmark publication in phycology (the study of algae).
  • He classified algae based on morphology, pigmentation, storage products, and mode of reproduction, laying the foundation for modern algal taxonomy.
  • Fritsch's research remains a critical reference for understanding algal biology.

Additional Information:

  • M.O.P. Iyengar is known as the father of Indian phycology, but his major contributions came after Fritsch.
  • William Henry was a chemist known for Henry’s Law, not related to algae.
  • Carolus Linnaeus developed the binomial nomenclature system in taxonomy in the 18th century, not specific to algae.

question:
A renowned scientist observed that the presence of green mould prevented the growth of bacteria. Who is the scientist and which discovery did this observation lead to?

SSC MTS 18/07/2022 (Evening)
option_1: Alexander Fleming, Chicken Pox vaccine
option_2: Edward Jenner, Chicken Pox vaccine
solution:
• In 1928, Alexander Fleming, a Scottish bacteriologist, observed that a green mould (Penicillium notatum) growing accidentally in one of his petri dishes was inhibiting the growth of Staphylococcus bacteria.
  • This observation led to the discovery of Penicillin, the world’s first true antibiotic.
  • Penicillin revolutionized medicine by providing an effective treatment against bacterial infections such as pneumonia, scarlet fever, and syphilis.
  • Fleming shared the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1945 with Howard Florey and Ernst Boris Chain, who helped in the mass production of penicillin.

Additional Information:

  • Edward Jenner is known for developing the smallpox vaccine, not penicillin.
  • Chickenpox is a viral disease, and its vaccine was developed much later, unrelated to Jenner or Fleming.

question:
Which ecologist’s research provided revolutionary new insights into how energy and nutrients move through the ecosystems ?

SSC CHSL 31/05/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Raymond L. Lindeman, an American ecologist whose work revolutionized the understanding of energy flow in ecosystems.
  • In 1942, Lindeman published a groundbreaking paper titled "The Trophic-Dynamic Aspect of Ecology", where he introduced the concept of trophic levels and described how energy decreases as it moves from producers to consumers through the food chain.
  • He quantified energy transfer efficiency between levels (around 10%), leading to the 10% Law of energy transfer.
  • His model laid the foundation for modern ecosystem ecology and energy flow diagrams used today.

Additional Information:

  • Arthur Tansley coined the term “ecosystem” in 1935.
  • Ernst Haeckel coined the term “ecology” in 1866.
  • Charles Elton introduced the concepts of food chains, niches, and pyramid of numbers in ecology.

question:
Who shared the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 2005 with Barry J Marshall for the discovery of the Helicobacter pylori bacterium and its role in gastritis and peptic ulcer disease ?

SSC CHSL 31/05/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• In 2005, the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded jointly to Barry J. Marshall and J. Robin Warren.
  • They were honored for their discovery of the bacterium Helicobacter pylori and its critical role in causing gastritis and peptic ulcer disease.
  • Their research overturned decades of medical belief that ulcers were mainly caused by stress or spicy food.
  • Marshall even ingested the bacterium himself to prove the link, which led to revolutionary changes in ulcer treatment using antibiotics.

Additional Information:

  • Paul Lauterbur: Won the Nobel Prize in 2003 for MRI imaging development.
  • Richard Axel: Nobel laureate in 2004 for work on the olfactory system.
  • Oliver Smithies: Won the Nobel Prize in 2007 for work in gene targeting in mice.

question:
In 1857, who was the first to experimentally demonstrate that the yeast responsible for making alcohol from sugar, and contaminating microorganisms found in normal air, Could sour fermentation?

SSC CHSL 02/06/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• In 1857, Louis Pasteur, a French microbiologist and chemist, was the first to experimentally demonstrate that:
    • Yeast is responsible for alcoholic fermentation, converting sugar into alcohol.
    • Airborne microorganisms (contaminants) could cause souring or spoilage of fermentation processes (like in wine and milk).
  • Pasteur's findings disproved the theory of spontaneous generation and established that fermentation is a biological process caused by living microorganisms.
  • His work laid the foundation for pasteurization, germ theory of disease, and modern microbiology.

Additional Information:

  • Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin in 1928.
  • Fanny Hesse introduced agar as a medium in microbiological cultures, but not related to fermentation.
  • Martinus Willem Beijerinck is known for discovering viruses and work in soil microbiology, much later than Pasteur.

question:
With whom did Camillo Golgi receive the Nobel Prize in 1906 for his work on the structure of the nervous system?

SSC CHSL 07/06/2022 (Morning)
option_4: Santiago Ramon y Cajal
solution:
• In 1906, Camillo Golgi shared the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with Santiago Ramón y Cajal.
  • Both were awarded for their groundbreaking work on the structure of the nervous system.
  • Golgi developed the "black reaction" (Golgi stain), a silver staining technique that made neurons visible in fine detail.
  • Cajal used Golgi's technique to demonstrate that the nervous system is made up of individual nerve cells (neurons), forming the basis of the Neuron Doctrine.
  • Interestingly, while Golgi supported the "reticular theory" (that neurons formed a continuous network), Cajal correctly argued for the "neuron theory", which was later proven accurate.

Additional Information:

  • Lina Aletti, Cesare Lombroso, and Ettore Marchiafava were not co-recipients or directly involved in this discovery.
  • This shared Nobel Prize is famous for being awarded to two scientists with opposing views.

question:
Antonie van Leeuwenhoek was known for which discovery in the late 17th century?

SSC CHSL 07/06/2022 (Afternoon)
option_1: Discovery of the properties of a stem ceil
option_2: Observation of bacteria and protozoa
option_3: Discovery of the role of ATP as the source of energy for cells
option_4: Discovery of nucleus in the cell
solution:
• In the late 17th century, Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, a Dutch scientist and microscopist, became the first person to observe and describe bacteria and protozoa.
  • Using a simple single-lens microscope he built himself, he observed "animalcules" (his term for microorganisms) in pond water, dental plaque, and other substances.
  • His observations, made around 1674, are considered the first recorded discovery of the microbial world.
  • He is often called the "Father of Microbiology" for this contribution.

Additional Information:

  • (a) The concept of stem cells and their properties was understood much later, in the 19th and 20th centuries.
  • (c) The role of ATP as the energy currency of the cell was discovered in the 20th century.
  • (d) The nucleus in cells was discovered by Robert Brown in 1831, not Leeuwenhoek.

question:
In 1838, who published an article discussing the structure and origin of plant cells?

SSC CHSL 09/06/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• In 1838, Matthias Schleiden, a German botanist, published an important article discussing the structure and origin of plant cells.
  • Schleiden proposed that all plant tissues are composed of cells, and that the cell is the basic unit of plant life.
  • His work laid the foundation for the Cell Theory, which he later co-developed with Theodor Schwann (who applied it to animals in 1839).
  • Schleiden’s observations emphasized the importance of the nucleus in cell development.

Additional Information:

  • Robert Brown discovered the nucleus in 1831 but did not establish a full theory on plant cell structure.
  • Rudolf Virchow contributed to cell theory later, in 1855, by stating “Omnis cellula e cellula” (All cells come from pre-existing cells).
  • Albert von Kölliker was known for his work in histology and embryology, but not for the 1838 plant cell discovery.

question:
In 1972, __________ coined the term ‘pyramid of numbers’ that represented the total numbers of individuals (population) present in each trophic level.

SSC CHSL 09/06/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• In 1972, Charles Elton, a British ecologist, coined the term "Pyramid of Numbers".
  • This ecological concept represents the number of individuals (population) present at each trophic level in a food chain.
  • In a typical pyramid of numbers:
    • Producers (like plants) form the base with the largest number.
    • Herbivores (primary consumers) are fewer.
    • Carnivores (secondary and tertiary consumers) are even fewer.
  • Elton’s concept helped in visualizing energy flow, population dynamics, and ecosystem structure.

Additional Information:

  • Eugene Odum is known as the "father of modern ecology" and emphasized ecosystem ecology.
  • Ernst Haeckel coined the term “ecology” in 1866.
  • Arthur Tansley coined the term “ecosystem” in 1935.

question:
For what discovery was Jan Evangelista Purkinje known in 1839 ?

SSC CHSL 10/06/2022 (Morning)
option_1: Proposed a lipid bilayer membrane
option_3: Coined the term protoplasm
solution:
• In 1839, Jan Evangelista Purkinje, a Czech physiologist, was credited with coining the term "protoplasm".
  • He used this term to describe the jelly-like substance inside cells, which is now understood to be a part of the cytoplasm, essential for cell functions.
  • Protoplasm was considered the living substance of the cell and a key component in early cell theory.

Additional Information:

  • (a) Proposed a lipid bilayer membrane – This concept was introduced later, in 1925 by Gorter and Grendel.
  • (b) Discovered plasma membrane – The term and structure were clarified in the late 19th to early 20th century.
  • (d) Discovered the nucleus – This was done by Robert Brown in 1831.

question:
In 1879, who observed cell division in salamander embryos, where cells divided at fixed intervals?

SSC CHSL 10/06/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• In 1879, Walther Flemming, a German cytologist, was the first to observe and describe cell division (mitosis) in salamander embryos.
  • He used improved microscopy and staining techniques to watch how the nucleus and chromosomes behaved during cell division.
  • Flemming found that cells divided at fixed intervals, and he meticulously documented the stages of mitosis.
  • His work laid the foundation for modern cytology and the understanding of cell cycle and division.

Additional Information:

  • Albert von Kölliker contributed to histology and embryology but did not discover mitosis.
  • Edwin Gorter is known for his work (with Grendel) on the lipid bilayer in 1925, unrelated to cell division.
  • The name Edwin Gorter is mistakenly repeated in the options; he is not associated with cell division research.

question:
In which year did Rudolf Virchow published an essay titled ‘Cellular Pathology’ in which he famously declared that “every cell arises from another cell”?

SSC CHSL 10/06/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• In 1855, Rudolf Virchow, a German physician and pathologist, published an influential essay titled “Cellular Pathology”.
  • In this essay, he famously stated: “Omnis cellula e cellula”, which means “Every cell arises from another cell”.
  • This declaration was a direct challenge to the outdated theory of spontaneous generation.
  • Virchow’s work became a key pillar of modern cell theory, specifically adding the third principle: that new cells are formed only from pre-existing cells.

Additional Information:

  • The original cell theory was formulated by Matthias Schleiden (1838) and Theodor Schwann (1839).
  • Virchow’s addition in 1855 completed the classical three-part Cell Theory:
    1. All living things are made of cells.
    2. The cell is the basic unit of life.
    3. All cells arise from pre-existing cells.

question:
Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG) is a vaccine for ______ .

SSC CGL 20/04/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG) is a vaccine used primarily for the prevention of Tuberculosis (TB).
  • It was developed in 1921 by Albert Calmette and Camille Guérin, from whom the vaccine gets its name.
  • The vaccine contains a live, attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis, a bacterium closely related to Mycobacterium tuberculosis (which causes TB).
  • BCG is especially effective in preventing severe forms of TB in children, such as TB meningitis and miliary TB.

Additional Information:

  • Typhoid is prevented using Typhoid vaccines like Vi polysaccharide or Ty21a.
  • Plague vaccines exist but are not commonly used today.
  • Mumps is prevented through the MMR vaccine (Measles, Mumps, Rubella).

question:
Who among the following developed the Cholera vaccine in 1885 ?

SSC MTS 06/10/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• In 1885, Jaime Ferrán, a Spanish physician and bacteriologist, developed the first cholera vaccine.
  • He prepared the vaccine using inactivated cholera bacteria and tested it during a cholera outbreak in Spain, making him the first to use a cholera vaccine in a mass vaccination campaign.
  • Ferrán's work was pioneering, though controversial at the time, and laid the foundation for future cholera immunization efforts.

Additional Information:

  • Edward Jenner developed the smallpox vaccine in 1796.
  • Jonas Salk developed the polio vaccine in the 1950s.
  • Léon Calmette co-developed the BCG vaccine for tuberculosis with Camille Guérin.

question:
Which scientist won the Nobel Prize in 1915 for describing the nature of the structure of chlorophyll in plants and also noted magnesium as the central element in its structure?

SSC CHSL 26/10/2020 (Afternoon)
solution:
• In 1915, Richard Willstätter, a German chemist, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his extensive research on plant pigments, especially chlorophyll.
  • He determined the chemical structure of chlorophyll, the green pigment responsible for photosynthesis in plants.
  • Willstätter's groundbreaking contribution was identifying that magnesium (Mg) is the central metal ion in the chlorophyll molecule.
  • His work significantly advanced the understanding of photosynthesis and plant biochemistry.

Additional Information:

  • James Watson is known for co-discovering the structure of DNA (Nobel Prize in 1962).
  • Werner Heisenberg won the Nobel Prize in 1932 for quantum mechanics (uncertainty principle).
  • Hermann Muller won the Nobel Prize in 1946 for discovering that radiation can cause genetic mutations.

question:
Christiaan Barnard is famous for:

SSC CGL 09/03/2020 (Evening)
option_1: First publishing tables of logarithms
option_2: Performing the world’s first human heart transplant
option_3: Delivering the world’s first test-tube baby
option_4: Cloning the first mammal ever
solution:
• Christiaan Barnard, a South African cardiac surgeon, is renowned for performing the world’s first successful human heart transplant.
  • This historic operation took place on December 3, 1967, at Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town, South Africa.
  • The recipient was Louis Washkansky, who lived for 18 days post-transplant, marking a major breakthrough in modern organ transplantation.
  • Barnard’s achievement brought global attention to transplant surgery and opened doors for future advancements in the field.

Additional Information:

  • (a) John Napier is credited with publishing the first tables of logarithms (1614).
  • (c) The world’s first test-tube baby, Louise Brown, was born in 1978 via IVF, pioneered by Dr. Robert Edwards and Patrick Steptoe.
  • (d) The first cloned mammal was Dolly the sheep in 1996, by Ian Wilmut and his team in Scotland.

question:
Whose invention led to the development of the polio vaccine?

SSC CPO 13/12/2019 (Evening)
solution:
• Jonas Salk, an American medical researcher and virologist, is credited with developing the first successful polio vaccine.
  • In 1955, Salk introduced the inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV), which was a major breakthrough in the fight against poliomyelitis—a disease that caused paralysis and death worldwide.
  • His invention dramatically reduced polio cases globally and laid the foundation for mass immunization campaigns.

Additional Information:

  • Linus Pauling was a chemist known for his work on chemical bonding and peace activism (Nobel laureate in Chemistry and Peace).
  • Robert Wellberg is not associated with polio research.
  • Ernst Haeckel coined the term ecology, not related to vaccine development.
